content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Excellent contribution! Adding the prime numbers in the description was really a good decision. I loved this challenge and had a lot of fun doing it, thank you!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This is a fun and nice clash, thank you for the detailed explanation in the statement!

Test 5 does not work with the given constraint "no primes > 114", because:
34554 = 2 x 3 x 13 x 443

Please fix this test. Otherwise, I like that you've added the prime numbers up to 113 in the description.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I like the idea of this contribution

I like to puzzle on this contribution - but I would hate to do it in a time-sensitive clash setting. It always takes me a bit of time to get the code for primes together (ah, I see in Ruby you just have 'primes' - but I do not know about such a thing for Python), then I need to think about an algorithm for getting the right powers, then some small errors, and then (just now) I run into my solution timing out at test & validator 4 so I would need to check for optimization of my code. For me it feels a tad too difficult for a clash. It might make for a nice easy puzzle.

Compliments on the explanation and visualization in the statement by the way, and, again, a very nice puzzle. I'd love to spend more than 5 minutes on this one :-).

Goal section
* Perhaps you can use the
```
multi-line
monospace
syntax
```
to format the example of 201 to make it look better?

Thanks.
Thanks, that's looking better now. Much appreciated.

Prime puzzles can definitely have a bit more prep time than other ones, so I can see why some people avoid them.

I might try to make the description a bit better, because there is a fairly easy way to solve this without too much challenge.

Basically, I mention that the prime-ary will never be greater than 9 digits, so you only need to check primes up to 23. (EDIT: wrong. Actually up to 3203. Digits up to nine just means no prime divides the number more than 9 times).

So, for each digit in your answer you can just test how many times that prime divides the number. You can even go right to left starting with 23 if you want and just trim the leading zeros.

So if you just make an array of the 9 primes from 2 to 23 and then map that into an array of how many times each number divides the input then those become the new digits. :)

Thanks for the feedback. jddingemanse said similar, so it's good to know it's a common feeling about it.

I could make the description a lot more direct and less story-based.

Basically, the problem is to find all the primes up to 113 and then test how many times they divide the input number. Then concatenate all those numbers into a string and print it backwards. If I put it that way, it's a lot easier to start solving it, right?
I see that test 5 is different now, thank you!

Thanks! It's great to know that the simplified version is fun to solve.
I guess I was worried that it'd be less fun if I explained the whole solution in the statement, so it's good to know you had fun and appreciated the prime numbers to avoid extra work. :)

Yes, you must have been trying it as I was fixing it! :) Thanks for checking it out!
I made it a lot more clear and detailed in my revisions. Thanks for approving. :)
I've simplified the description now to be a lot more direct in breaking down how to solve it. Hopefully it's more approachable now?

That’s much better!

This is very clever by the way.
Did you just totally make this concept up??

Thanks. :)

Yeah, I thought of it independently, but I'm sure others have had the same idea before me. It's fun to play with a notation for numbers based on multiplication rather than addition (like decimal and binary are), but it's using prime decomposition which is already a well-known fingerprint/signature of integers and then just writing the prime exponents as a concatenated string, so I assume it's been done before.

Ah, I totally missed the 'up to 23'.

For my understanding: the "Here we just stick to 0-9." (statement) is about the 'to the power digits', while 'No digits in the prime-ary number will exceed 9' (constraints) implies that only primes up to 23 are used, correct? I mixed those two up: I thought that this constraint phrase meant the same as what you state in the statement.

Actually, I still do not understand the way you have phrased the constraint. 'No digits in the prime-ary number will exceed 9' sounds to me that you will have, with a three-digit-length prime-ary, maximum 999 (and never 10 10 10 so to say). But if instead you mean to say that only the first 9 primes (prime 1 up to 9, i.e.  up to 23) are used, then instead that implies that 'The prime-ary number will always consist out of maximum 9 digits' (i.e. your highest prime-ary will be 999999999, max 9 characters).
So, if I understand it correctly, you actually have two different constraints (while you only mention one):
- No digits in the prime-ary number will exceed 9;
- The prime-ary number will exist out of maximum 9 digits.

Oh sorry, my mistake. I oversimplified my own clash haha. You're right, the digits up to 9 is just about the multiplicities, I test primes up to 3203 currently.
I'll have to have a think about whether to simplify it a bit, because I can see why dealing with so many primes is hard. I'll remove the '23' part, that was a mistake.

Or.. easy puzzle instead of Clash? Then no further simplification is needed, and you might even in some way introduce not only 0-9 but all of them (for example, the weird 16 3 14 primary for 6.75E16 if I'm not mistaken)

Thanks for the help.

I decided to just make it a bit easier and keep it as a clash.
I've made it so that you only need to deal with the first 30 primes (up to 113) to pass all tests and validators. Clashers could even just define an array listing them all from if they don't want to generate them algorithmically.

I've made it a lot easier now I think. I changed the description to give people the list of primes they will need and also fully break down how to solve the puzzle. I hope it leads to better success rates for clashers. :)
Thanks for your feedback!
